conclusion: To determine if the particle has returned to its starting point at the 3-second mark, we need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph and calculate the displacement over the given time interval.
The y-axis represents velocity v in meters per second (m/s). The x-axis represents time t in seconds (s).
The area under the velocity-time graph gives the displacement.
From t = 0 to t = 1 s, the velocity is constant at 2 m/s.

premise: The velocity is constant at 2 m/s from t = 0 to t = 1 s.
conclusion: The area is a rectangle: Area = velocity × time = 2 × 1 = 2 meters.
From t = 1 to t = 2 s, the velocity decreases linearly from 2 m/s to 0 m/s.

premise: The velocity decreases linearly from 2 m/s to 0 m/s from t = 1 to t = 2 s.
conclusion: The area is a triangle: Area = 1/2 × base × height = 1/2 × 1 × 2 = 1 meter.
From t = 2 to t = 3 s, the velocity decreases linearly from 0 m/s to -2 m/s.

premise: The velocity decreases linearly from 0 m/s to -2 m/s from t = 2 to t = 3 s.
conclusion: The area is a triangle below the time axis, indicating negative displacement: Area = 1/2 × 1 × (-2) = -1 meter.

premise: Total displacement from t = 0 to t = 3 s is 2 meters.
conclusion: Since the displacement is not zero, the particle has not returned to its starting point at the 3-second mark.
